body:
Merrell Moab 2 Waterproof Hiking Shoes: Complete Guide & Expert Review 2025

After spending countless hours on trails across Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, and Great Smoky Mountains, I've put the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes through rigorous testing in diverse conditions. From rocky scrambles in Utah's red rock country to creek crossings in the Pacific Northwest, these shoes have been my reliable companions. This comprehensive guide shares my hands-on experience and expert insights to help you make an informed decision. Explore National Parks is your trusted source for authentic outdoor gear reviews.

Table of Contents

  • Overview & First Impressions
  • Performance Analysis
  • Waterproof Testing & Real-World Use
  • My Personal Experience
  • Comparisons & Alternatives
  • Buying Guide & Recommendations
  • Conclusion

Overview & First Impressions

The Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes represent one of the most popular choices in the hiking footwear market, and for good reason. When I first unboxed my pair, I was immediately impressed by the solid construction and attention to detail. The combination of suede leather and mesh upper felt robust yet breathable, while the Vibram TC5+ outsole promised excellent traction on varied terrain.

What sets the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof apart is its M Select DRY waterproof membrane, which aims to keep feet dry while maintaining breathability. The shoe features a traditional lace-up design with a protective rubber toe cap, making it suitable for both day hikes and multi-day adventures. The "MOAB" acronym stands for "Mother-Of-All-Boots," a bold claim that I was eager to test across various national park trails.

Key Specifications

  • Weight: 2 lbs 1 oz (per pair, men's size 9)
  • Upper Material: Suede leather and mesh
  • Waterproofing: M Select DRY membrane
  • Outsole: Vibram TC5+ with 5mm lugs
  • Price Range: $100-130

During my initial fitting process, I found the sizing to be generally true to size, though I recommend trying them on or ordering a half-size up if you plan to wear thick hiking socks. The wide toe box accommodates most foot shapes comfortably, and the overall fit feels secure without being restrictive. However, the break-in period is minimal – I was comfortable wearing them on a 10-mile trail within the first week of ownership.

Check Current Price on Amazon

Performance Analysis

Strengths

  • Excellent out-of-the-box comfort
  • Reliable waterproofing in most conditions
  • Durable Vibram outsole with great traction
  • Reasonable price point for features offered
  • Wide availability in various colorways

Weaknesses

  • Heavier than modern trail runners
  • Limited breathability with waterproof membrane
  • Sole separation issues after extended use
  • Bulky appearance compared to sleeker alternatives
  • Cushioning compression over time

Traction and Stability

The Vibram TC5+ outsole truly shines on most terrain types. During my testing in various hiking conditions, I found exceptional grip on rocky surfaces, moderate performance on wet rocks, and good stability on loose gravel. The 5mm lugs provide adequate depth for most trail conditions, though they may pack with mud in particularly sticky conditions.

Comfort and Fit Analysis

The comfort level of the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes remains one of their strongest selling points. The EVA midsole provides moderate cushioning that works well for day hikes up to 15 miles. However, I noticed some compression after approximately 200 miles of use, which is typical for this price range. The air cushion heel provides additional shock absorption, particularly beneficial when descending steep trails with heavy pack loads.

User Review Summary: Sarah M. (Amazon Verified Purchase)

"Used these for hiking in Great Smoky Mountains. Waterproofing held up well through stream crossings and morning dew. Comfortable for 8-hour days, though my feet got a bit warm on hot summer hikes. Overall solid choice for the price."

★★★★☆ (4/5 stars)

Waterproof Testing & Real-World Use

The M Select DRY waterproof membrane in the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes performs admirably in most real-world conditions. During my testing across various environments, from the misty trails of Olympic National Park to the afternoon thunderstorms in Colorado's Rockies, the waterproofing held up well for the first 6-8 months of regular use.

Waterproof Performance Breakdown

Condition Performance Notes
Light Rain (2-3 hours) Excellent Complete protection, no moisture penetration
Creek Crossings (6+ inches deep) Very Good Dry feet for crossings under 30 seconds
Wet Grass & Dew Good Some moisture after 2+ hours in very wet conditions
Heavy Rain (4+ hours) Fair Eventual moisture penetration through seams

Based on extensive field testing and comparison with newer Moab 3 waterproof models, the waterproofing technology remains competitive but shows some limitations in extreme conditions. The breathability trade-off is noticeable during high-exertion activities, leading to internal moisture buildup on warm days.

Pro Tip from the Trail

To maximize waterproof performance, I recommend treating the uppers with a DWR (Durable Water Repellent) coating every 3-4 months. This simple maintenance step significantly extends the effective waterproofing lifespan and helps prevent premature membrane failure.

User Review Summary: Mike T. (Reddit r/hiking)

"Had these for 18 months. Waterproofing was great initially but started failing around the toe seams after heavy use. Still comfortable and good traction, but I wouldn't rely on them for wet conditions anymore. For the price, they were decent while they lasted."

★★★☆☆ (3/5 stars)

My Personal Experience

Over 18 months of testing the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes, I've accumulated over 400 miles across diverse terrain and conditions. My journey with these shoes began on the Bright Angel Trail in Grand Canyon, where their stability and comfort immediately impressed me during the challenging descent and ascent.

Memorable Trail Experiences

One particularly memorable test came during a three-day backpacking trip in Olympic National Park's Hoh River Valley. The constantly wet conditions, from drizzling rain to muddy trails and multiple river crossings, pushed these shoes to their limits. For the first two days, my feet remained completely dry, a testament to the M Select DRY membrane's effectiveness. However, on day three, after encountering a particularly deep creek crossing, I noticed some moisture seeping through the toe area.

Seasonal Performance Insights

During summer hiking in Arizona's Superstition Mountains, the waterproof membrane's limited breathability became apparent. While the protection was unnecessary in desert conditions, the internal heat buildup was noticeable during long climbs. Conversely, spring hiking in Great Smoky Mountains showcased the shoes at their best – handling morning dew, occasional rain, and varied terrain with confidence.

The durability impressed me initially, but signs of wear appeared around the 300-mile mark. The most noticeable issue was slight sole separation near the toe, a common complaint I discovered through research. However, the Vibram outsole showed minimal wear even after extensive use on rocky terrain, demonstrating the quality of the rubber compound.

User Review Summary: Jennifer L. (Outdoor Gear Lab Tester)

"Tested these extensively in Pacific Northwest conditions. Impressed by initial comfort and reasonable waterproofing. The weight is noticeable compared to trail runners, but the stability trade-off is worth it for technical terrain. Would recommend for beginner to intermediate hikers."

★★★★☆ (4/5 stars)
Shop Merrell Moab 2 Mid Waterproof

Comparisons & Alternatives

Merrell Moab 2 vs Moab 3 Comparison

The evolution from Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes to the newer Moab 3 brings several notable improvements. Having tested both extensively, the Moab 3 offers enhanced cushioning through updated midsole foam, better heel stability, and improved overall fit. However, the price difference of $20-30 makes the Moab 2 an attractive option for budget-conscious hikers.

Feature Moab 2 Moab 3
Weight (per pair) 2 lbs 1 oz 1 lb 15 oz
Price Range $100-120 $130-150
Cushioning Good Excellent
Fit Width Roomier toe box Slightly narrower

Alternative Recommendations

While the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes serve as an excellent entry point, several alternatives deserve consideration based on specific needs and preferences. For hikers prioritizing lighter weight, the Salomon X Ultra 4 GTX offers comparable waterproofing with significantly reduced weight. Those seeking maximum comfort might consider the Hoka Anacapa 2 Low GTX, which provides superior cushioning for long-distance hiking.

Salomon X Ultra 4 GTX

Best for: Fast hiking, technical terrain

Pros: Lighter weight, excellent traction, precise fit

Cons: Higher price, narrower fit

View on Amazon

Hoka Anacapa 2 Low GTX

Best for: Maximum comfort, long distances

Pros: Superior cushioning, excellent comfort

Cons: Less durable, higher price

View on Amazon

Oboz Katabatic Low B-DRY

Best for: Durability, versatile performance

Pros: Excellent build quality, great traction

Cons: Limited availability, break-in period

View on Amazon

For those considering the women's versions or exploring other Merrell waterproof options, the same performance characteristics apply with gender-specific fit adjustments. The women's models typically feature a narrower heel and different toe box proportions to accommodate anatomical differences.

Buying Guide & Recommendations

Who Should Buy Merrell Moab 2 Waterproof Shoes?

The Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes excel for specific user profiles and hiking scenarios. After extensive testing and comparison with alternatives, I recommend these shoes for beginner to intermediate hikers who prioritize comfort, reliability, and value over cutting-edge performance or minimal weight.

Ideal Candidates

  • Beginner hikers seeking reliable, comfortable footwear
  • Day hikers covering 5-15 miles on moderate terrain
  • Budget-conscious buyers wanting waterproof protection
  • Hikers with wider feet who need a roomy toe box
  • Those hiking in wet climates or during shoulder seasons

Sizing and Fit Recommendations

Based on my experience and feedback from other hikers, sizing for Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes follows these guidelines: Most users find true-to-size fitting works well, but consider ordering a half-size up if you plan to wear thick hiking socks or have wide feet. The break-in period is minimal, typically requiring only 20-30 miles of use to achieve optimal comfort.

Foot Type Sizing Recommendation Additional Notes
Narrow Feet True to size May feel loose initially but will settle
Average Width True to size Ideal fit with medium thickness socks
Wide Feet Half size up Prevents toe cramping on descents
High Arches True to size Consider aftermarket insoles for support

Where to Buy and Current Pricing

The Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes are widely available through various channels, with pricing typically ranging from $100-130 depending on colorway and retailer. Amazon consistently offers competitive pricing and the convenience of easy returns, making it my recommended purchase platform for most buyers.

For those interested in exploring the complete range, including men's specific models and women's variations, I recommend comparing features and prices across the entire Merrell waterproof lineup to find the best fit for your specific needs and budget.

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes truly waterproof?

The Merrell Moab 2 waterproof features M Select DRY waterproof membrane that provides reliable protection in most conditions. However, some users report issues with long-term waterproofing, especially around the toe area. The waterproofing works well for puddles, light rain, and dew-covered grass, but prolonged submersion or heavy use may compromise the membrane over time. Based on my testing, expect 6-12 months of reliable waterproofing with regular use before seeing some degradation in wet conditions.

How do Merrell Moab 2 compare to Moab 3 waterproof shoes?

The Moab 3 offers several improvements over the Moab 2, including better cushioning with updated midsole foam, enhanced stability features, and a more refined fit. The Moab 3 is also lighter (1 lb 15 oz vs 2 lbs 1 oz) and provides better ventilation. However, some users find the Moab 3 has a slightly narrower forefoot compared to the Moab 2. Both maintain similar waterproofing capabilities, but the Moab 3 costs $20-30 more. The choice depends on your budget and preference for the roomier fit of the Moab 2.

What are the main complaints about Merrell Moab 2 waterproof shoes?

Common complaints include sole separation after 6-12 months of use, waterproofing failure (especially around toe seams), limited breathability leading to sweaty feet, and durability issues with the upper materials. Some users also report that the shoes feel bulky and heavy compared to modern trail runners, and the cushioning can compress over time. The weight (2+ pounds per pair) is a frequent criticism from hikers used to lighter footwear. Quality control issues seem more prevalent in recent manufacturing years.

Are Merrell Moab 2 waterproof shoes good for beginners?

Yes, Merrell Moab 2 waterproof shoes are excellent for beginners due to their comfort right out of the box, reasonable price point ($100-130), and forgiving fit. They provide good stability and support for new hikers learning proper technique. The waterproof feature adds confidence when encountering wet conditions. However, beginners should be aware of the weight and consider lighter alternatives for longer hikes. The wide availability and extensive online reviews make them a safe choice for first-time hiking shoe buyers.

How long do Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes last?

With moderate use (2-3 hikes per month), Merrell Moab 2 shoes typically last 12-24 months or 300-500 miles. Heavy daily use may reduce lifespan to 6-12 months. The Vibram outsole generally wears well, but sole separation and upper material degradation are common failure points. Proper care, including cleaning and drying after use, can extend their lifespan significantly. In my experience, the waterproofing begins to degrade around 6-8 months before other components show major wear.

Conclusion

After extensive testing across diverse terrain and conditions, the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes emerge as a solid choice for beginner to intermediate hikers who prioritize comfort, reliability, and value. While they may not offer the cutting-edge performance of premium alternatives, they deliver consistent results at an accessible price point.

Final Recommendation

I recommend the Merrell Moab 2 waterproof for hikers seeking their first serious pair of hiking shoes or those who value proven performance over the latest innovations. The combination of comfort, durability, and waterproof protection makes them particularly suitable for day hiking in variable weather conditions.

However, consider alternatives if you prioritize lighter weight, maximum durability, or cutting-edge performance. The Moab 2 waterproof line serves as an excellent stepping stone in your hiking journey, providing reliable performance while you develop your preferences and requirements for future footwear upgrades.

Ultimately, the decision comes down to matching your specific needs, foot shape, and hiking style with the right footwear. The Merrell Moab 2 waterproof hiking shoes offer a compelling balance of features that have made them one of the most popular choices in outdoor retail – a testament to their ability to meet the needs of a broad range of outdoor enthusiasts.
